The originator of the doormat quote was Eleanor Roosevelt: No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
that quote is from Eleanor Rooevelt, another lady known for her wit and good sense.
Mrs Roosevelt may have come up with the idea, but Ann Landers restated it for the the everyday person.

Here's a favorite from Ann Landers, as it happens (our local paper carried her and not Abby): "No one can treat you like a doormat without your permission."

Wonderful tribute, NYT.

Oh, how I will miss you Abby and have missed your sister. Even when it wasn't cool in the 60's to read you, much less agree or follow your advice, you really were right on in retrospect.

The thing I liked was that you and your sister also grew during all those decades. You weren't above mentioning that you were wrong at times or had changed your mind about issues. Your growing and changing over time taught me a very important lesson about life, that I am still reminded of even today.

RIP dear Abby.

I started reading Dear Abby as a kid and still have a daily newspaper habit because of her.
Best advice: MYOB (mind your own business).
May God rest your soul.
Ditto.

I am going to be 65 next month.  When I was a young girl, the Dear Abby and Ann Landers columns were the best part of my day!  Thank you for your gracious obituary, New York Times!  I still have your paper to enrich my every day while I am still fortunate enough to wake up in the morning!

I am sick of reading that the mentally ill are not "prone to violence" which seems to be a popular way for psychologists, psychiatrists, and others to deflect reality.  For example, those who claim that autistic children do not display "violent behavior" and rather, tend to be the opposite are refusing to acknowledge the truth.  Frequently, and I repeat, frequently, autistic children become so frustrated with their inability to "communicate" that they have temper tantrums and breakdowns and freak outs.   Obviously, that IS violent behavior and should be understood to be exactly that.  Perhaps those in the mental health industry, and I do mean, industry, should realize that "violent" behavior does not equate to "evil" behavior - no one is trying to "stigmatize" mental illness.

That's funny. Your article only talked about "mental illness". It almost sounds like you are pushing an agenda to reduce the rights of all people with mental illness instead of just this group that only has a very slight increase in violence. Why would that be? Wouldn't you logically craft your policy around those who are prone to violence instead of stigmatizing everyone? That is unless you have other motives. Where does the Mental Illness Policy Org get its funding?
I believe you meant instead to respond to Appelbaum/Lieberman.

While well-intentioned, the author disingenuously quotes rates of violence. Are persons with mental illness more violent than others? The definitive answer is, "it depends who is mentally ill'.

Studies of the 40 to 50 percent of Americans whom mental-health experts claim have some “diagnosable mental disorder” support the claim that “persons with mental illness are not more violent than others.” But the populations in those studies are disingenuously large.

Studies of the 5 percent of Americans with the most serious mental illnesses -- primarily schizophrenia and treatment-resistant bipolar disorder -- who are receiving treatment also support the claim of mental-health experts that "persons with mental illness are not more violent than others". But these studies prove only that treatment works, not that persons with mental illness are not more prone to violence.

Studies of the 5 percent of subgroup of the most seriously mentally ill who are not in treatment and are psychotic, delusional, or hallucinating, or are off treatment that has previously prevented them from being violent, are in fact more prone to violence than others.

When people ask if mentally ill are more violent than not, this is the group they are usually referring to, not their friends on Prozac. Stats on violence may be found here: http://mentalillnesspolicy.org/consequences/mental-illness-violence-stat...

I would agree, fund mental health care not as a safety issue but merely because people need it as part of our overall health care system.

Also start supplying free viagra to those rabid military assault weapons owners who apparently need something that's big, shoots and goes bang.

You are right that it would be helpful to know more about what treatment or lack of treatment that these individuals were getting. It would also be helpful to learn more about what families and friends were thinking or feeling in relation to these men. For example, I know that there was a professor at Virginia Tech who was very concerned about the man who later committed the atrocities there, but was unable to get the authorities to take any kind of effective action. Holmes was seeing a psychiatrist, but that does not necessarily mean he was taking medications. Even if he was prescribed medications, we don't know whether he actually was taking them or not. I have not seen any credible reporting that Lanza was ever diagnosed with a mental illness. There was mention of autism, but that is different.

People with mental illness are just as different as people with physical illness. Some treatments work for some, and not for others. I worked with people diagnosed with chronic mental illness for 28 years. I have seen where medications made a significant difference in many peoples' lives for the better. There were lots of other things involved also: a good doctor/patient relationship, caring case management services, safe, affordable housing, etc.

You are right that big Pharma has lots of power. Attention needs to be paid and regulations enforced when necessary.

The drugs, by and large, do not work. I say this as the mother of a 31 year old who has received every diagnosis in the book, and every drug available.

I object to the description of Adam Lanza's mother as "doting mom." She was desperately seeking help for her son, and she died in the attempt. "Doting" is an insult.

When will we admit that we just plain don't know much about mental illness, and institutionalize the hopelessly sick so that at least they can have decent care, and the rest of us can be protected?

We need to face facts. Yes, there are thousands of people denied mental health treatment. But the last two mass shooters that horrified the nation were not among them. They were in the system and getting medicated. James Holmes was a grad student in neuroscience who spent his days surrounded by psychiatrists, and was seeing a top-flight one at the med school. He saw her at least through June 11, 2012, perhaps longer -- almost right up to that horrible night. You don't see a psychiatrist in America any more without getting at least one medication -- often three or four. What was Holmes taking? As for Adam Lanza, here was an upper middle class boy whose doting mom was always dragging him to doctors to deal with his issues. Some sources had him taking the antipsychotic Fanapt. Undoubtedly he was tried on multiple antipsychotics, anticonvulsives, antidepressants. This is what we do with troubled kids and teens in America.

Can someone admit it's not working? Even if you doubt the evidence that these pills provoke violence in a small but significant percentage of takers, at least it's time to admit they are not the magic bullets that the pharmaceutical industry claims they are. We need journalists with the guts to push past this industry's massive political and economic clout and come to grips with a deeply flawed system that has done more for Pharma's stock prices than for our mental health -- or our safety.

We need government to build mass transit instead of highways jammed with gas-guzzling automobile each with one or two passengers. We need to build dykes around our major population centers on coastal areas such as New York City for example.
Instead we are paying twice as much to cleaning up the damage afterwards. Events such as hurricane Sandy are going to become more frequent as the earth’s temperature and water levels rise.
We can increase the standard of living for the majority of Americans instead of letting the few gluttons amass family fortunes that are wasted on self-indulgence and concentrated power.
American Exceptionalism means providing a Great Society for everyone.
